Co-authored-by: Andrew Yang


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
- [x] depends on: #19461

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ffdb4bf7dd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19245/commits/ffdb4bf7ddbeefae54499ebb7eb026480b411883)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Finset` (new file)|532|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ cast_finsetInf'`
`+ cast_finsetSup`
`+ cast_finsetSup'`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19461~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
~~It looks like the `Group/Finset` lemmas went missing?~~ oops, now I see!
Those are about `inf'`/`sup'` so should probably be nolinted at the declaration
Probably `s` should be implicit, and I think in all the other new lemmas as well?

This is an exception to the rule that arguments that can be inferred from later ones should be implicit. The reason is that `hs` can be filled in by unification from both the LHS and RHS when rewriting, so it won't need to be provided. In contrast, the `s` argument can be used to disambiguate rewrites
Is it worth making this a definition? (Can be deferred)
Don't think so. I have inlined it
Consider `assert_not_exists GroupWithZero`
Well spotted
Let's add a more helpful docstring here: for instance it certainly shouldn't be the same as the one for GroupWithZero
What about now?

I usually find lemmas like these quite a bit more useful in the opposite direction, especially for rewriting. It's typically cleaner to push the `sup'` inside as much as possible, in order to use arithmetic operations on the overall equation. What do you think?

When I use these lemmas, usually further simplications become available when I push the multiplication inside, eg it cancels out a division, or it goes into an `ite` with one side being `0`, etc... so I like them this way. Generally (/always?), distributivity lemmas are stated as "non-distributed version = distributed version" for this particular reason that further simplifications are available after distributing

Interesting, I have exactly the opposite experience, that further simplifications are available when keeping the multiplication on the outside. For example, `s.sup' hs f - a = b` allows algebraic manipulations involving the entire equation, and these usually mean the goal is easier to prove.

Similarly when writing informally, we typically keep as little inside a supremum as possible: `Sup_i (f i + c)` is almost always viewed as less simple than `Sup_i (f i) + c`.

But let's see how these ones get used. Certainly I'll be almost exclusively using them in reverse :)
oof, this is an unfortunate name!
I agree :/
We should also have versions of these on the other side. I'd say the GroupWithZero ones should be in a different PR.
Added the other side version of this one. I doubt the other side version of the `div` is true
This docstring doesn't make much sense to me - both `Finset.sup'_add` and `Finset.sup'_add'` say that the other works for canonically ordered monoids.
This is definitionally a special case of `sup_add`, right, or am I missing something? If it is, then I'd say we should deprecate this in favour of that.
I'm not sure it is, no, because it is specialised to `WithBot M` where `âŠ¥ + a = âŠ¥`
Don't these lemmas also work for something much weaker than semiring? It looks like this one needs less than `sup'_mulâ‚€`.
Now this file is just about casts interacting with `Finset.sup`, so maybe a docstring describing it that way would be nice

```suggestion
variable [LinearOrderedSemiring R] {s : Finset Î¹}

set_option linter.docPrime false in
@[simp, norm_cast]
lemma cast_finsetSup' (f : Î¹ â†’ â„•) (hs) : ((s.sup' hs f : â„•) : R) = s.sup' hs fun i â†¦ (f i : R) := by
  induction hs using Finset.Nonempty.cons_induction <;> simp [*]

set_option linter.docPrime false in
@[simp, norm_cast]
lemma cast_finsetInf' (f : Î¹ â†’ â„•) (hs) : (â†‘(s.inf' hs f) : R) = s.inf' hs fun i â†¦ (f i : R) := by
  induction hs using Finset.Nonempty.cons_induction <;> simp [*]
```

these can all be easily golfed and generalised
Oh nice. I didn't think an adjoint-less proof was possible
following the above, this one doesn't need floor semiring any more.

```suggestion
  comp_sup_eq_sup_comp _ (by simp) (by simp)
```

btw, @YaelDillies, I think we should have the version of `comp_sup_eq_sup_comp` that works for `sup'`, asks for the finset to be nonempty and has no assumption about what happens to bot. Its proof should be analogous to the ones I gave above, but it gives those two lemmas as easy special cases. I'd normally say that that can be a different PR but this one is small enough that you can combine them if you want.
It already exists, actually ðŸ˜‰
Oh! Then I'm still correct that it should exist ;)

pullRequest.title: feat: interaction of `Finset.sup` and `Nat.cast`
